Perhaps the most dispiriting exchange all week was when Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, asked Mr. Zuckerberg about Facebook’s market power, and the notion that it is too dominant for any other social network to compete with.

If it wanted to, Congress could address the issue of hateful content by adopting strict hate speech laws like the ones that exist in Germany, which make social platforms liable if they fail to remove hate speech in a timely manner.

It could address the problem of transparency in political ads by passing the Honest Ads Act, a bill that would subject online political ads to similar disclosure standards as TV and radio political ads.
And it needs to demonstrate that it has the political resolve to push these changes through, even as the tech industry furiously lobbies against them, as it undoubtedly will.
Lawmakers do not need to be computer scientists, or to come up with an omnibus bill to address all of Facebook’s flaws in one fell swoop.
But first, it needs to understand which pieces need fixing, and how to carry out fixes without creating unintended consequences.
All of these are theoretically possible outcomes, depending on which of Facebook’s many issues lawmakers decide to address.
Or, if it decides that Facebook is just too darn big, Congress could spearhead an effort to break it up.
(Mr. Zuckerberg has already indicated that he supports the measure, so this should be an easy one.)
It could pick off one issue at a time, consult with the experts and take a piecemeal approach.
